column3: Integration and application of theoretical foundations and development of clinical skills in nurse anesthesia practice.

column2: NURS 548 - Clinical Nurse Anesthesia Practicum/Seminar V
column3: Integration and application of theoretical foundations and development of clinical skills in nurse anesthesia practice.

column2: NURS 549 - Clinical Nurse Anesthesia Practicum/Seminar VI
column3: Integration and application of theoretical foundations and development of clinical skills in nurse anesthesia practice.
Advanced practice nursing of the pediatric population and families; health promotion and nursing interventions for comprehensive and preventative care.
Advanced practice nursing of the pediatric population and families; role refinement in health maintenance and restoration.

column2: NURS 560 - Advanced Practice of Mental Health Nursing I
column3: Etiologies of mental health, dysregulation, and person-centered recovery including evidence-based treatments. Skills in therapeutic relationship development, advanced holistic assessment, diagnostic reasoning, and therapeutic modalities are emphasized.

column2: NURS 561 - Advanced Practice Mental Health II
column3: Advanced practice nursing in community settings for families and groups with actual and potential mental health problems.

column2: NURS 562 - Care of the Pediatric Patient with an Acute Illness
column3: Pathophysiology of acute minor illnesses in the pediatric population.

column2: NURS 563 - Care of the Pediatric Patient with Chronic Conditions
column3: Pathophysiology and management of chronic conditions in the pediatric patient.

column2: NURS 565 - Teaching Practicum for Healthcare Professionals
column3: Individually designed teaching experience in healthcare and academic settings.

column2: NURS 566 - Educational Principles and Strategies for Healthcare Professionals
column3: Analysis and application of educational principles and strategies for academia, consumer health, and continuing education.

Application of advanced assessment skills, health promotion concepts, and pathophysiologic alterations to develop beginning clinical-decision making skills in the primary care of individuals and their families with common health problems; clinical experience in the role of nurse practitioner in a variety of settings.
Emphasizes increasingly advanced nursing competencies in the primary care of individuals and their families in all developmental stages.
Clinical experience in a variety of settings emphasizing advanced nursing competencies in the primary care of individuals and their families in all developmental stages.

Advanced nursing management of complex health problems of individuals and their families in all developmental stages; role refinement and exploration of major practice issues; clinical experience in a variety of settings.

column2: NURS 574 - Practice Issues: Clinical Nurse Specialist
column3: Collaborative deliberation on issues related to the clinical nurse specialist roles.
Topic is determined by faculty and student interest.

column2: NURS 578 - Technology in Health Professions Education
column3: Exploration and analyses of instructional technology and health information systems that enhance learning.
Introduction of basic principles of epidemiology with special emphasis given to clinical practice applications.
Non-thesis option. Individually designed supervised research or other scholarly experience.

column2: NURS 583 - Clinical Nurse Anesthesia Practicum/Seminar VII
column3: Integration and application of theoretical foundations and development of clinical skills in nurse anesthesia practice.
Additional opportunities for advanced nursing practice.  Objectives to be developed collaboratively by student and faculty.

Exploration and analysis of nursing human resource management that focuses on change and performance management, staff development, succession planning, coaching and guiding skills, mentoring, and cultural and generational competencies.

Explore, analyze, and apply selected organizational, management, and leadership theories; financial principles of delivery of nursing services; and the adaptive processes of health care organizations for executive nursing administration.
Explore, analyze, and apply organizational, management, and financial principles and theories to mid-level nursing administration.

Exploration and analysis of healthcare quality management to include current quality of care issues, research and evidence-based practice, creating and sustaining accountable organizations/high-reliability organizations, principles of Continuous Quality Improvement, Total Quality Management, Six Sigma, Balanced Scorecards, and LEAN.

Exploration and analysis of healthcare reimbursement, concepts and principles in healthcare financial planning/management, capital budgeting, strategic planning/ project management, and effective management of labor costs essential to nurse administrators.

column2: NURS 601 - Philosophy and Knowledge Development for Nursing Science
column3: Philosophy of science related to nursing science; theory analysis and evaluation; and theory construction based on concept development.

column2: NURS 602 - Advanced Statistical Methods for Health Care Research
column3: Apply foundational knowledge of inferential statistics to multivariate analyses of health care data, including multiple linear regression, repeated measures analysis, mixed linear models, and factor analysis.

column2: NURS 603 - Nursing Inquiry and Research Design
column3: Introduction to the philosophical, theoretical, and design aspects of nursing inquiry.
Exploration of concepts and competencies related to population health for advanced practice nursing.

column2: NURS 605 - Middle-Range Theoretical Formulations for Nursing Science Development
column3: Extant and emerging middle-range theories instrumental in nursing science development.
A practical, skills-oriented course of selected topics pertaining to preparation of federal-formatted grant proposals.
Critique and application of selected qualitative nursing research methods.
Critique and application of selected quantitative nursing research methods.
Supervised individual or group research experience under guidance of faculty.

column2: NURS 610 - Review and Critique of Scientific Literature
column3: Development of competencies for critical analysis and synthesis of literature in selected focus area within nursing science.

Advanced quantitative methods in nursing research including development, selection, and utilization of instruments. Advanced multivariate statistical strategies. Emerging concepts in quantitative methods.

column2: NURS 612 - Health and Health Care Policy
column3: Interdisciplinary examination of contemporary health, health problems and policy responses; public policy decision-making processes; and multi-stakeholder perspectives, roles, influence, and interactions.

column2: NURS 613 - Nursing Leadership in Complex Systems
column3: Analysis and evaluation of leadership in transforming health and healthcare in complex systems.
Individually designed, mutually beneficial practicum, field or internship experiences with a faculty and/or community member in a variety of settings/situations.

column2: NURS 615 - Research Ethics in the Health Sciences
column3: Issues relevant to conducting health sciences research with an emphasis on conflict of interest, responsible authorship, policies for handling misconduct, policies handling safe recruitment and retention of study participants, and data management.

column2: NURS 616 - Chemistry and Physics for DNP Nurse Anesthesia
column3: Integration and application of chemistry, physics, and biochemistry principles to nurse anesthesia practice.

column2: NURS 617 - Clinical Anatomy for DNP Nurse Anesthesia
column3: Examination of foundational histological and gross anatomical principles for the safe delivery of nurse anesthesia care.

column2: NURS 618 - Clinical Anatomy Lab for DNP Nurse Anesthesia
column3: Application of foundational histological and gross anatomical principles for the safe delivery of nurse anesthesia care through cadaveric and simulated experiences.
Comprehensive study of specific human organ systems’ physiologic and pathophysiologic concepts in health promotion and anesthetic care across the lifespan.

column2: NURS 620 - Philosophical and Theoretical Foundations for Practice
column3: A critical examination of the philosophical, historical, and theoretical context of knowledge.
Comprehensive study of specific human organ systems’ physiologic and pathophysiologic concepts in health promotion and anesthetic care across the lifespan.
Identification, critique, and evaluation of existing evidence related to clinical problem of interest to determine best practices.

column2: NURS 623 - Population Health in a Global Society
column3: Application of theory, research, and intervention strategies to improve global health.
Examination of current practices in project design, management, implementation, evaluation and sustainability.
Critical analysis of economics in health and healthcare focusing on the healthcare market, financing, and delivery in the United States.
Application of financial management concepts and techniques in decision-making in health services organizations.
Detailed study of general pharmacological principles and medications for therapeutic decision-making in nurse anesthesia clinical practice.

column2: NURS 629 - Basic Principles of DNP Anesthesia
column3: Examination of technology, equipment, and basic principles for nurse anesthesia practice.
Advanced planning for the DNP Scholarly Project.
Individually designed practicum to implement and evaluate the DNP Scholarly Project.
Completion of the DNP Scholarly Project.

column2: NURS 635 - General Principles of DNP Anesthesia I
column3: Anesthesia care management exploration in homeostasis, disease states, and organ systems’ diagnostic and surgical procedures based on basic sciences, evidence-based practice, and safety and quality’s conceptual frameworks.

column2: NURS 636 - General Principles of DNP Anesthesia II
column3: Anesthesia care management exploration for special populations, homeostasis, disease states, and diagnostic and surgical procedures based on basic sciences, evidence-based practice, and safety and quality’s conceptual frameworks.

column2: NURS 637 - General Principles of DNP Anesthesia III
column3: Anesthesia care management exploration for acute and chronic pain, radiological principles, and safe practices in non-operating room anesthesia experiences.
Extensive exploration of standards of care, safety and quality, emerging issues, technological, economic and legal regulation and critical appraisal of nurse anesthesia’s professional role.

column2: NURS 640 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum I
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “novice” nurse anesthesia clinical student in perioperative preparation and evaluation of equipment, medications, patient risk stratification and airway management.

column2: NURS 641 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum II
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “novice” nurse anesthesia clinical student in ASA I patients’ anesthetic care.

column2: NURS 642 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum III
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “advanced beginner” nurse anesthesia clinical student in ASA IE and II patients’ anesthetic care.

column2: NURS 643 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum IV
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “advanced beginner” nurse anesthesia clinical student in ASA IIE & III patients’ anesthetic care.

column2: NURS 644 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum V
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “competent” nurse anesthesia clinical student in ASA IIIE, and IV patients’ anesthetic care and subspecialty surgical, diagnostic and anesthesia procedures.

column2: NURS 645 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum VI
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “competent” nurse anesthesia clinical student in ASA IVE and V patients’ anesthetic care, and subspecialty surgical, diagnostic and anesthesia procedures.

column2: NURS 646 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum VII
column3: Integration of anesthetic theoretical underpinnings by the “proficient” nurse anesthesia clinical student for the ASA VE and ASA VI patients’ anesthetic care and subspecialty surgical, diagnostic and anesthesia procedures.

column2: NURS 647 - DNP Anesthesia Clinical Practicum VIII
NURS 650 - Wellness, Development, and Behavior of the Pediatric Population
column3: Advanced practice nursing of the pediatric population and families focusing on well child care, issues of development and behavior, and nursing interventions for comprehensive and preventative care.

column2: NURS 651 - Pediatric Nurse Practitioner I: Care of the Pediatric Patient with an Acute Illness
column3: Pathophysiology of acute minor illnesses in the pediatric population.

column2: NURS 652 - Pediatric Nurse Practitioner II: Care of the Pediatric Patient with Chronic Conditions
column3: Pathophysiology and management of chronic conditions in the pediatric patient.

column2: NURS 653 - Clinical Experiences in the Pediatric Populations
column3: Pathophysiology and management of chronic conditions in the pediatric patient.
Physiology and pathophysiology of complex acute, chronic and critical illnesses in pediatric patients.

column2: NURS 655 - Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner
column3: Etiologies of mental health, dysregulation and person-centered recovery including evidence–based treatments. Skills in: therapeutic relationship development, advanced holistic assessment, diagnostic reasoning and therapeutic modalities are emphasized.

Clinical experience in adult mental health, dysregulation and person-centered recovery including evidence–based treatments across the lifespan. Skills in: therapeutic relationship development, advanced holistic assessment, diagnostic reasoning and therapeutic modalities are emphasized.

column2: NURS 657 - Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner II
column3: Advanced practice nursing in community settings for families and groups with actual and potential mental health problems.
Clinical experience in advanced practice nursing in community settings for families and groups with actual and potential mental health problems.

Application of advanced assessment skills, health promotion, and pathophysiologic alterations to develop beginning clinical decision-making skills in the primary care of individuals and their families.

Application of advanced assessment skills, health promotion, and pathophysiologic alterations emphasizing advanced clinical decision-making skills in the primary care of individuals and their families.
Advanced nursing management of complex health problems of individuals and families in all developmental stages.

column2: NURS 662 - Clinical Practice: Family Nurse Practitioner
column3: Clinical practice in the role of the Family Nurse Practitioner in a variety of health care settings.

column2: NUTR 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.

column2: NUTR 509 - Graduate Seminar in Public Health
column3: Cross-listed: (See Public Health 509.)

Overview of nutrient functions in fundamental biological processes (in non-disease states), including energy transformation, metabolic regulation, and growth/development, all with emphasis on application in community and public health settings, including the Dietary Guidelines for Americans (DGA), Dietary Reference Intakes (DRI), and nutrition-related evidenced-based guidelines.

column2: NUTR 511 - Advances in Carbohydrate, Lipid and Protein Metabolism
column3: The physiological impact of dietary carbohydrates, lipids and proteins, with an emphasis on nutritional and hormonal regulation of intermediary metabolism, bioenergetics and gene regulation.

column2: NUTR 512 - Advances in Vitamin and Mineral Metabolism
column3: Advances in the requirements, utilization, metabolism and physiological impact of micro-nutrients with an emphasis on vitamins and minerals in the context of human nutrition.

Case study, simulation and experiential practice in community nutrition; development of cultural awareness, knowledge, skills, and experience; work with instructor and preceptor(s) to conduct a community nutrition needs assessment; plan, deliver and evaluate a culturally appropriate group nutrition education session; use quality improvement methods to improve nutrition-related community programs, services, or projects.

Experiential practice in community nutrition at local public health and community nutrition agencies; development of cultural awareness, knowledge, skills, and experience; participate in policy development and advocacy activities; plan, implement, and evaluate a population-focused nutrition intervention, culminating in a poster presentation for faculty, preceptors, students, and community members.

column2: NUTR 515 - Field Study in Community Nutrition
column3: Personal participation in and analysis of state or regional community nutrition program. Location of in-depth study to be selected in consultation with instructor.

Progression to independent clinical nutrition practice application in a community healthcare clinic setting and development of a collection plan for clinical outcomes data. Introduction to clinical nutrition practice in acute care settings.

column2: NUTR 519 - Analysis of Practice in Community Nutrition
column3: Analysis of community nutrition practice from a systems-level to professional practice levels.

column2: NUTR 520 - Clinical Nutrition Outcomes Data Analysis and Interpretation
column3: Data analysis, development of data displays, preparation of an abstract and poster or presentation for presentation of findings in a professional setting.
Individual eating habits and disorders, evaluation strategies for effectiveness of helping process.
Review of theoretical framework and communications skills important in the counseling process.

column2: NUTR 524 - Public Health Nutrition: Community Assessment, Intervention, and Evaluation
column3: Examination of the socio-ecological model and nutrition-related protective and risk factors at each level of the model; community nutrition needs assessment, including defining nutrition-related services, gaps, and health disparities in target populations; development of population-focused goals and objectives to improve health; development of population-focused nutrition intervention and policy plans; development of evaluation plans for nutrition-related interventions, policies, and programs. Includes field experiences.

Diagnosis, pathophysiology, management, evidence-based guidelines for nutrition intervention, and case scenario discussion of musculoskeletal diseases/disorders, HIV, inborn errors of metabolism, critical care, nephrology.

Independent clinical nutrition practice application in a community healthcare clinic setting. Collection of clinical outcomes data based on previously developed plan. Clinical nutrition experience in complex acute care conditions.

column2: NUTR 527 - Advanced Clinical Practice and Mentorship
column3: Advancement of independent clinical nutrition practice in a community healthcare clinic setting to include mentorship of undergraduate students as they are introduced to clinical nutrition practice.
Experiential learning in the healthcare foodservice setting with a focus on operations and management roles.
Scientific method, study design, data interpretation, and critical evaluation of current nutrition literature.
Experience in food-related industry or agency under supervision of faculty member.
Advanced study in nutrition.
Recent advances in nutrition or food systems administration.

column2: NUTR 602 - Advanced Topics in Nutrition Science
column3: Comprehensive individual study and group discussion of topics related to current problems in nutrition.
Topical readings from the current research literature will be assigned each week and discussed in class the following week.

column2: NUTR 621 - Physiological Basis for Diet and Disease
column3: Altered nutrient needs as result of metabolic changes that occur in selected disease states.

column2: NUTR 624 - Public Health Nutrition Systems, Programs and Services
column3: An in-depth examination of food and nutrition-related public health systems, programs, and services; an overview of public health and public health nutrition essential services in the US; an analysis of leadership and management roles of community and public health nutritionists in system- and community-level programs to support and improve population health; delineation of system-thinking theories and development of community-based nutrition-related systems models and diagrams.

Advanced nutrition principles related to needs across the life cycle will be explored in-depth (i.e., pregnancy, fetal development, lactation, infancy, early-, middle-, and late-childhood, adolescence, and young-, middle-, and late-adulthood). Factors associated with the ability to follow the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, at each relevant stage, will be discussed. An emphasis will be placed on the impact of these concepts on the maternal and child population.
Funding mechanisms, scientific grant writing, advanced research design/methodology in nutrition, and peer review.

column2: PHIL 420 - Topics in History of Philosophy
column3: One or more figures or movements from antiquity through mid-20th-century.
Metatheory of formal logic and philosophy of logic.

column2: PHIL 441 - Global Justice and Human Rights
column3: Issues such as justice between distinct and diverse political communities; universal human rights; and moral issues in environment, trade, and development.
Topic varies.
Topic varies.

column2: PHIL 460 - Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHIL 480 - Topics in Metaphysics and Epistemology
PHIL 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.
Paper workshop (writing, revising papers, getting papers ready to publish).

column2: PHIL 520 - Topics in Ancient or Medieval Philosophy
column3: Intensive critical work on major philosopher or school.
Intensive critical work on major philosopher or school.
Intensive critical work on major philosopher or school.
Intensive critical work on themes in late 20th-century philosophy.

column2: PHIL 540 - Topics in Ethics or Value Theory
PHIL 542 - Topics in History of Ethics
column3: Dominant movements in history of ethics.
Content may vary.

column2: PHIL 560 - Topics in the Philosophy of Science

column3: Topics vary.
Topics vary.

column2: PHIL 577 - Topics in Philosophy of Mind
column3: Relation of mental to physical and the role of words in discourse about mental activities, thinking and feeling.

column2: PHIL 590 - Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
column3: Philosophical problems concerning social and political life: family, state, freedom, justice; major theoretical responses: anarchism, social contract, Marxism.
Topically focused seminar with emphasis on development of philosophical skills and methods. Required of all first-year graduate students in philosophy.

column2: PHIL 620 - Topics in Ancient or Medieval Philosophy
PHIL 626 - Topics in Metaphysics and Epistemology
column3: Topics vary.

column2: PHIL 640 - Topics in Ethics or Value Theory

column3: Content may vary.

column2: PHYS 405 - Science, Technology, and Public Policy
column3: The United States faces challenges which include climate change, energy independence, human genomics, nano-technology, and modified food crops. The process by which public policy decisions are made, currently and historically, in the federal government is examined with an eye to the role scientists, advocacy groups, industry, researchers, national laboratories and individual citizens play in setting public policy. The role played by political values in setting the research agenda is explored.

Fundamental principles of quantum mechanics. The Uncertainty Principle. Solutions of the Schrödinger equation in one dimension. Bound states. Angular momentum. The Hydrogen atom. Required course for all physics majors.

column2: PHYS 412 - Introduction to Quantum Mechanics II
column3: Methods of calculation: perturbation theory, the variational principle, and the WKB approximation. Introduction to scattering theory. Quantum statistics. Applications to atomic, molecular, nuclear, and condensed matter physics. This course is targeted toward students who intend to pursue graduate studies in physics.
Transmission of light in uniform, isotropic media, reflection and transmission at interfaces. Mathematics of wave motion and interference effects. Rudiments of Fourier optics and holography.
Electrostatics and magnetostatics in vacuum and in matter. Time-dependent electric and magnetic fields. Maxwell’s equations. Required course for all physics majors.

Methods of calculation in electrostatics and magnetostatics. Conservation laws. Potentials. Electromagnetic waves. Relativistic electrodynamics. Radiation. This course is targeted toward students who intend to pursue graduate studies in physics.

Introduction to fundamental and modern techniques in experimental physics, and to the theory and practice of measurement and data analysis. Selected experiments in nuclear, atomic, molecular and solid state physics, and modern optics.
Topics of current interest.
Advanced research techniques under supervision of staff research director whose research area coincides with interests of student.

column2: PHYS 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.
Lectures and discussion on current research topics. Continuous registration required for current graduate students.

Introduction to experimental methods of spectroscopy through hands on operation of FTIR, Raman, NMR, photoelectron, laser and mass spectrometers. Principles and hazards of cw and pulsed lasers, radiation detectors, photomultiplier tubes, image intensifiers, image converters; high-vacuum systems including cryogenic-based devices, data acquisition techniques including lock-in amplifiers, box-car integrators, digital electronics methods and micro-computer data acquisition.
Topics in geometrical, physical, Fourier, and nonlinear optics and introductory laser physics. Extensive use of computer calculations and design of practical and sophisticated optical systems.

column2: PHYS 513 - Problems in Theoretical Physics I
column3: Fundamentals of physics: classical mechanics (Newtonian mechanics, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics) and electrostatics and magnetostatics.

column2: PHYS 514 - Problems in Theoretical Physics II
column3: Fundamentals of physics: electrodynamics, relativity, and quantum mechanics.

Fundamental principles of quantum mechanics, angular momentum, electron spin, particles in electric and magnetic fields, perturbation theory, variational methods, scattering theory; second quantization, quantization of electromagnetic field, emission, absorption, and scattering of light, bremsstrahlung, pair creation and annihilation. Application of quantum mechanics to problems of atomic, molecular, nuclear, and solid state physics.

Fundamental principles of quantum mechanics, angular momentum, electron spin, particles in electric and magnetic fields, perturbation theory, variational methods, scattering theory; second quantization, quantization of electromagnetic field, emission, absorption, and scattering of light, bremsstrahlung, pair creation and annihilation. Application of quantum mechanics to problems of atomic, molecular, nuclear, and solid state physics.
Variational formulation, Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations, constraints, canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory and action-angle variables.

Review of electrostatics, magnetostatics, and quasi-static problems; Maxwell’s field equations and their solutions in dielectric and conducting media; electrodynamics and relativity, retarded potentials and gauge transformations, radiation produced by accelerating charges.

Ergodic theory, classical ensemble theory, quantum mechanical ensembles, relation of statistical mechanics to thermodynamics, transport theory and approach to equilibrium, phase transition, fluctuations and correlations.

Elementary solid state physics. Bonding in solids, free-electron-gas theory of metals, crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, energy bands, phonons, semiconductors and semiconductor devices, optical properties of solids, phenomenological description of superconductivity, magnetism, and other forms of broken symmetry.

column2: PHYS 556 - A Survey of Modern Nuclear Physics Topics
column3: Covers essential problems in nuclear physics with emphasis on topics from high, medium and low-energy nuclear physics. Models of the nucleon and nuclei will be surveyed and contemporary experimental methods will be presented in the context of applications and other areas of physics.

column2: PHYS 571 - Mathematical Methods in Physics I
column3: Linear vector spaces, matrices, tensors, curvilinear coordinates, functions of a complex variable, partial differential equations and boundary value problems, Green’s functions, integral transforms, integral equations, spherical harmonics, Bessel functions, calculus of variations.
Numerical methods for solution of physical problems, use of digital computers, analysis of errors.
Especially assigned theoretical or experimental work on problems not covered in other courses.
(a) Mechanics; (b) Radiation; (c) Heat and Thermodynamics; (d) Electricity and Magnetism; (e) Modern Physics.
Survey of research problems and methods. Topics of current interest.
Advanced problems.

Applications of lasers to spectroscopy of atomic and molecular systems; absorption, laser-induced fluorescence, and Raman spectroscopy; molecular and atomic coherence, quantum beats, resonance fluorescence, photon echoes, self-induced transparency; saturation and Doppler-free spectroscopy; laser cooling and trapping.

Nonlinear optical susceptibilities, wave propagation in nonlinear media, sum-frequency and difference frequency generation, harmonic generation, parametric amplification and oscillation, stimulated Raman processes, two- and multi-photon processes, four-wave mixing and phase conjugation, transient coherent optical effects and free induction decay, optical breakdown and nonlinear effects in plasmas.

Quantum theory of emission and absorption of radiation; frequency-dependent susceptibility; coherence theory; field quantization and coherent photon states; interaction of radiation with atoms; photon optics, counting and higher-order coherence; atomic scattering phenomena.

column2: PHYS 611 - Advanced Quantum Mechanics and Field Theory
column3: Survey of problems and methods. Topics of current interest.

column2: PHYS 612 - Advanced Topics in Quantum Field Theory
column3: Renormalization, Lamb shift, anomalous magnetic moments, gauge theories, electroweak theory, quantum chromodynamics, grand unified theories, and advanced topics in laser physics and quantum optics. Topics vary according to interest of students, instructor, and present state of physics.

Stellar evolution: hydrostatic equilibrium, energy production and transport, star birth, main sequence, red giants, variable stars, and stellar explosions. General relativity and gravitation, white dwarfs, neutron stars, pulsars, and black holes.

Galaxies and the interstellar medium. Active galaxies, quasars, and supermassive black holes. Large-scale structure, the expanding Universe, cosmologies, big bang, cosmic background radiation, inflation, dark matter, formation of structure, and fate of the Universe. The Planck scale and quantum gravity.
Survey of research problems and methods. Topics of current interest.
Advanced problems.
Survey of elementary particle physics: experimental methods, conservation laws, invariance principles, and models of interactions.
Advanced topics - quark models, electroweak interactions, and unification of elementary forces.

column2: PHYS 642 - Advanced Topics in Modern Physics
column3: Advanced theoretical or experimental topics not covered in other courses.

Developing computer algorithms for solving representative problems in various fields of physics, celestial dynamics in astrophysics, boundary value problems in electromagnetism, atomic and nuclear structures, band structure in solid state physics, transport problems in statistical mechanics, Monte Carlo simulation of liquids, fitting and interpolation of data, correlation analysis, or optimization strategy.

Second quantization. Models of fermion and boson systems. Interacting electrons at the mean field level: Hartree-Fock and density functional theory. Linear response theory (I): Thomas-Fermi and Lindhard models, Friedel oscillations. Semi-classical theory of transport, transport in quantum/topological systems, electron-phonon interactions, charge density waves, Kohn anomalies, BCS theory of superconductivity.

Magnetism: microscopic mechanism, spin-wave theory, magnons. Strongly correlated systems:  Hubbard model, Mott insulators, charge transfer insulators, many-body methods including Green’s functions. Spectral functions. Linear response theory (II). Impurities: Kondo problem, periodic Anderson model, High-Tc superconductivity.

Management methods as applied to retail and wholesale nurseries and landscape contracting firms. Methods of producing liners, container and field-grown woody liners, containers and field-grown ornamental plants.

column2: PLSC 421 - Native Plants in the Landscape
column3: Native plants and plant communities as a basis for landscaping and environmental restoration. Weekly lecture coupled with either an outing or service practicum of invasive exotic plant removals or planting of natives. Study and work sites will primarily be demonstration projects of the University of Tennessee Environmental Landscape Design Lab. They include local schoolyard habitats, greenways, wetlands, streambanks, and shorelines.

column2: PLSC 429 - Field Study of Public Horticulture Institutions
column3: Extended 10-12 day field study of various public horticulture institutions such as botanical gardens, arboreta, historical grounds, zoos, conservatories, cemeteries, and nature preserves.

Principles of greenhouse operation and management for commercial crop production. Greenhouse construction and operation, crop scheduling, and cost accounting. Environmental inputs and cultural practices as they affect plant physiological processes and influence plant growth and development. Weekend field trips may be required.
Botanical description, geographical distribution, general cultural practices of warm and cool season vegetables, small fruits, and deciduous tree fruits.
Agronomic principles of forage and field crop production, establishment, fertilization and management practices will be discussed using forage crops as the primary model.
Principles and techniques of photography as they relate to plants and gardens. Study of equipment options and field shooting under various weather conditions and in different seasons.

column2: PLSC 437 - Public Garden Operations and Management
column3: An analysis of year-round operations and management of public gardens. Case studies involving time and labor management, budget development and management, implementation of volunteer programs, information dissemination methods for public outreach, management of grounds and facilities using the University of Tennessee Institute of Agriculture Gardens as a model.
Methods of design, materials, and construction techniques for specialized components of the landscape industry. Irrigation systems, outdoor lighting, garden ponds and water features.
Principles of weed interference, integrated management, and herbicide selectivity and behavior. Specific recommendations for various crop and non-crop situations.

column2: PLSC 462 - Professional Development in the Turfgrass Industry
column3: Exposure to career development opportunities in turfgrass science and management.
Case studies of turfgrass management issues and discussion of their resolution. Development of problem solving skills in areas related to turfgrass management.

column2: PLSC 470 - Professional Practices for the Green Industry
column3: Professionalism, ethics, sales, sales proposals, budgeting, managerial skills, estimating, and contract management in the green industry. Students will additionally learn about professional involvement in industry related organizations.

column2: PLSC 480 - Sustainable Landscape Design Synthesis and Application
column3: Comprehensive application of design, construction, and management knowledge, as well as contemporary representation skills to develop sustainable landscapes. Projects address a variety of site and contextual challenges at a range of scales. Advancement of professional practice skillsets as they relate to client engagement and project management.
Practical application of digital hardware and software as it relates to the exploration and synthesis of landscape design and planning projects.

Communication for public horticulturists through written, oral and visual media. Emphasis on communication skills using proper writing techniques and grammar for print media, brochure design using desktop publishing, slide show development, oral presentations, and video use for educational and informational presentations in ornamental horticulture.

column2: PLSC 501 - Special Topics in Plant Sciences
column3: Topics to be assigned.

column2: PLSC 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.
Library, field, or laboratory project under supervision of faculty member.
Presentations and discussion of topics.
Discussion and readings related to the seed as a biological system: its formation, development, dormancy, germination and viability.

Application of ecological concepts to management of horticultural, agronomic and biofuel cropping systems. Examination of plant physiological ecology, population ecology, community ecology, and ecosystem ecology within the context of agroecosystems; discussion of current research in agroecology; assessment of sustainability of cropping systems from environmental, economic, and social perspectives.

column2: PLSC 525 - Research Ethics for the Life Sciences
column3: How good research conduct and knowing the rules of science can enable success in life science research. Bioethics is not a focus.
Cross-listed: (See Entomology and Plant Pathology 530.)

Physiological and ecological principles of plants and the relation of those principles to plant responses to the environment. Water relations, gas exchange, stress physiology, seed biology, plant competition, plant defense.

column2: PLSC 536 - Ecology of Grazing Land Systems
column3: Multi-university, field-oriented course. Components and functions of grazing lands and how these vary in different ecoregions; research needs, objectives and techniques in soil-plant-animal research; forage-livestock ecology and systems in grazing lands (cropland, pastureland, rangeland and forestland); role of forages in conservation practices, wildlife habitats, and sustainable agriculture; and industries involved with forages and livestock. Requires two-week field trip, inclusive report, and examination.
Effects of plant nutrition on biochemical and physiological processes in plants.
Identification, classification, and management of turfgrass pathogens. Recommendations and development of management plans for golf course, athletic field, and home lawn turfgrasses.
Principles and scientific basis of turfgrass culture. Adaptation, ecology, physiology, climatic influences on grass culture. Clipping and water management; design.
Construction and management of root-zones for home lawns, golf courses, and athletic fields.

Biological study and collection of arthropods that challenge maintenance of healthy grasses, turf, and sod. Review and discussion of sampling/monitoring strategies and decision-making guidelines to help manage turfgrass pests.
General principles and techniques used in plant modification. Principles of molecular and transmission genetics as applied to plant biotechnology and plant improvement.

Introduction to general principles, practices and techniques used to breed plants, select traits, and develop crop cultivars: including biomass feedstock crops. Concepts discussed will range from quantitative and population genetics, historical through conventional plant breeding (through self- and cross-pollinations) and hybridization, then end with exploration of contemporary approaches to improve plant traits including genetic engineering.

Lectures will discuss recombinant DNA technology, molecular assisted breeding of economically important crops, gene cloning and transformation technologies. Examples will be given of food and ornamental crops, pharmaceuticals, and renewable energy sources produced using biotechnology as well as potential risks of this technology. Labs will include electrophoresis, tissue culture, plasmid preps, genomic DNA preps, PCR, plant transformation, genomic techniques.

Identification of turf adult and seedling weeds, applied chemical control strategies, integrated weed management (including mechanical and cultural practices). Concepts discussed will include turfgrass weed ecology and invasiveness, herbicide regulations and an overview of select herbicidal modes of action.

Application of statistics to interpretation of biological research. Notation, descriptive statistics, probability, distributions, confidence intervals, t- and chi-square tests, analysis of variance, mean separation procedures, linear regression and correlation.

Supervised experience in teaching. May involve preparation of lectures and teaching aids, preparation and supervision of laboratory exercises, evaluation of student performance, and for second-year graduate students, responsibility for course delivery.

column2: PLSC 571 - Design and Analysis of Biological Research
column3: Cross-listed: (See Animal Science 571.)

column2: PLSC 591 - History and Culture of International Gardens and Landscapes
column3: International travel experience will provide opportunities to learn how historic European estates, gardens, and arboreta reflect the climate, topography, history, philosophical social structure, art and politics at the time of their creation. Course will focus on observation of local plant material, study of different garden and landscape design styles, and will foster an appreciation of international cultures.
Application of horticulture and design principles and practices in supervised, professional setting, approved by department.
Independent study. Current topic related to technology, science or design.
Preliminary research and investigation of dissertation research topic.

column2: PLSC 605 - Advanced Topics In Plant Sciences
column3: Topics may range from contemporary approaches and innovations in Crop Physiology and Ecology, Plant Breeding and Genetics, to Meta-Analyses.

Journal club format emphasizing active class participation as a mechanism to explore the field of plant genomics. Each student will be required to lead the exploration of specific topics and will present a combination of three lectures and/or journal club discussions on the assigned topic.

Principles of Weed Science with emphasis on herbicide chemistry, herbicide effects on plant physiology, the analysis of herbicide residues in soils and plants, weed biology, and methods to conduct research under field and laboratory conditions. Offered in fall, alternate (even) years.

Principles and methodologies targeting genetic gain for crop improvement. Concepts of qualitative and quantitative trait improvement. Parental germplasm, hybridization, population formation, inbreeding, genetic variance, heritability, selection methods, molecular genetic markers, genetically engineered crops.

Supervised experience in teaching. May involve preparation of lectures and teaching aids, preparation and supervision of laboratory exercises, evaluation of student performance, and responsibility for course delivery. May also involve new course development whether traditional classroom or online.

column2: POLS 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.

column2: POLS 510 - Scope and Methods in Political Science
column3: Procedures of analysis in political science.
Methods for planning and executing research, from case studies to experimental designs: development of research questions and hypotheses; measurement issues; and validity of inferences.
Methods and techniques in quantitative political analysis: univariate and bivariate statistics.
Methods and techniques in quantitative political analysis: multivariate model building.

column2: POLS 514 - Research Design and Methodology in Public Administration
column3: Basic assumptions and techniques of research in public administration; measurement, analysis, and reporting of data.
Introduction to maximum likelihood estimation with applications to political science. Discrete choice analysis, censored and truncated variables, event history analysis, and sample selection models.

column2: POLS 516 - Dynamic Models in Political Science
column3: Introduction to time series methods in political science. Discusses the problems that arise when regression methodologies are applied to time series and pooled time series data and their solutions.

Aimed at the newcomer to formal models, beginning with the basic components of game theory and spatial modeling and then moving on to their application across the fields of political science in such areas as international conflict, elections, judicial politics, and the study of political institutions.

column2: POLS 518 - Bayesian Modeling in Political Science
column3: Introduction to Bayesian methods and Hierarchical Linear Models (HLM). How to build more sophisticated models using Bayesian methods, how to apply these methods to data analysis in political science research, and how to deal with hierarchical data in an empirical model. Simulation techniques and related statistical tools are introduced.

column2: POLS 519 - Non-Statistical Approaches to Political Science Research
column3: The goal of this course is to familiarize political science graduate students with various non-statistical approaches used to conduct original research. Epistemologies of quantitative political science research, case studies, comparative case designs, historical analysis, field research, qualitative interviewing, documents as data, and ethnography.
Survey of literature, approaches to research and analysis, critical examination of major works, and overviews of research in various sub fields.
Systematic examination of the structure, functions and powers of the American presidency as they have evolved from the founding to the present.
Formal, empirical and theoretical approaches to and models of the institutional workings of Congress and the behavior of legislators.

column2: POLS 535 - Public Opinion and Political Socialization
column3: Explores the meaning and measurement of public opinion and contemporary research on the topic; including questions of rationality, tolerance, and party identification.

column2: POLS 536 - Campaigns, Elections, and Voting Behavior
column3: Surveys theory and research of American campaigns and elections, with an emphasis on presidential and congressional contests.

column2: POLS 537 - Political Parties and Interest Groups
column3: Theoretical and empirical examination of the structure, functions and operations of political parties and interest groups.

column2: POLS 539 - State and Local Government and Politics
column3: Theoretical and empirical analysis of government, politics, policymaking and public administration at the state and local levels.
Examination of published research dealing with judicial behavior, judicial policymaking, and courts and political actors.

column2: POLS 542 - Legal Foundations of Public Administration
column3: Aspects of public law affecting government agencies. Topics include enabling legislation, municipal charters, intergovernmental agreements, planning and zoning, eminent domain, personnel management and governmental liability.

column2: POLS 543 - Law, Regulation and Public Policy
column3: Policymaking by executive agencies through rulemaking, enforcement and adjudication; legislative, executive and judicial control of agency actions.
Theoretical, formal and empirical analysis of the roles, functions and decision-making processes of public policymakers, including legislative, executive and judicial actors.

Overview of contemporary environmental policy and its evolution. Examines the roles of values in the environmental arena. Provides a framework for policy analysis and analytical tools for selection and choosing among policy options.
Overview of public administration theory and function.
Analysis of current policy problems involving production, distribution, consumption and conservation of energy.
An overview of the history, scope, and management of not-for-profit organizations.
Development and implementation of sustainable development approaches and strategies for local communities.
Strategies and techniques for identification and analysis of public problems and policy solutions.
Examination of public administration in context of American political system, policy making and political roles of public administrators and agencies.

Principles and techniques of public finance at state and local levels: budget preparation, execution and audit, risk management, capital planning, major tax structures, economic forecasting, cash management, and debt administration.
Interpersonal and leadership skills, techniques and methods for planning, decision making, and implementation of management strategies in public sector.

column2: POLS 564 - Human Resource Management in Public Organizations
column3: Intensive analysis of contemporary issues, challenges, methods and strategies related to effective management of human resources in public sector.

column2: POLS 566 - Public Service Ethics and Values
column3: Moral-ethical-value dilemmas confronting administrators in American political system.
Selected topics in modern governments.
Analysis of decision making in security affairs. Topics covered include deterrence theory, crisis stability, nuclear strategy, and the political uses of military coercion.
Selected topics dealing with political problems of less developed countries.

column2: POLS 573 - War, Peace, and Grand Strategy
column3: An exploration of the military, economic, and social sources of great power competition in international politics.

column2: POLS 574 - Area Seminar in Comparative Government and Politics
column3: Selected topics in area studies: African, Asia, Latin America, Middle East, Soviet Union and Eastern Europe or Western Europe.

column2: POLS 579 - College Teaching in Political Science
column3: Pedagogical, technical, practical and ethical issues associated with teaching political science at the college level.
Survey of literature and major aspects of international politics.
History of planning, structure and development of urban areas, operations of contemporary planning, trends and issues.

column2: POLS 595 - Readings and Special Problems in Political Science
POLS 597 - Readings in Two Fields of Political Science
column3: Selected topics in two fields from among American Politics, Comparative Politics and International Relations.
Discussion of issues pertaining to teaching, research, and service for political scientists in academic and applied settings.

column2: POLS 610 - Special Topics in Empirical Theory and Methodology
column3: Advanced methods and procedures of analysis in political science.

column2: POLS 639 - Special Topics in American Government and Politics
column3: Advanced study of selected topics.
Problems in one or more public policy areas from political and administrative perspectives. Topics selected by instructor.

column2: POLS 660 - Contemporary Perspectives on Public Administration
column3: Development of theory in public administration: contemporary critiques and alternatives.

column2: POLS 668 - Special Topics in Public Administration
column3: Analysis of selected issues and problems in public administration.

column2: POLS 670 - Special Topics in Comparative Government and Politics
column3: Research into selected topics.

column2: POLS 673 - Comparative Political Economy: Advanced Industrial Countries
column3: Examines comparative political economy through research questions and scholarly works that focus on the advanced industrial countries.

Provides the analytical tools necessary to evaluate the legality of events under international law. Presents the law relevant to politics, such as the use of force, human rights, war crimes, international courts, principles of jurisdiction, and air, space and sea law.
Theoretical explanations for the causes and processes of war and international disputes or crises.

column2: POLS 686 - Arms Control, Deterrence and Nuclear Nonproliferation
column3: Challenges to U.S. and global security created by the existence of nuclear weapons and power.

column2: POLS 688 - Special Topics in International Politics
column3: Selected issues and problems in international politics. Specific content determined by instructor.

column2: PORT 400 - Portuguese for Speakers of Another Romance Language
column3: Accelerated class for beginning students of Portuguese with strong background in another Romance language. Introduction to grammar, reading, and culture of Portugal and Brazil.
Current Brazilian cultural, political and racial issues placed in a historical perspective with a comparative emphasis. Topics may vary.

column2: PORT 432 - Topics in the Literature and Culture of the Portuguese-speaking World
column3: Examination of the socio-political environment, literary works, and other important cultural practices of the Portuguese-speaking world. Topics may vary.
Explores the frontiers of cognitive psychology in areas such as attention, language use, memory, problem-solving, and concept formation.
Study of theory and technique through supervised experience in small groups.
Physiological and psychological theories of perception. Emphasis on audition and vision.
History of the psychology of religion with an examination of various philosophical and empirical orientations. Exploration of the psychological function of religion for individuals and society.

column2: PSYC 420 - History and Systems of Psychology
column3: History of psychological thought. Classical approaches and recent developments.
Psychological factors related to health and illness, including stress, personality, and environment. Applications of psychological treatments to physical illness.
Current psychosocial trends and their influence on personal adjustment and mental health. From scientist-practitioner perspectives of theory, research, and application.

Descriptive, theoretical and research aspects of abnormal development in children and adolescents are covered including, but not limited to, autism, ADHD, depression, eating anorexia and bulimia, and learning disabilities.
Traditional and contemporary theoretical conceptualizations and strategies in counseling psychology practice.
Biological, psychological, and social factors in gender. Importance of gender roles and stereotypes for behavior and experience.

Issues of race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, gender, spirituality, sexual orientation, and ability level as related to the theory, research, and practice of psychology will be examined. Focus will be on increasing personal self-awareness and knowledge of multicultural issues.

Theories and research about subjective well-being, neuropsychological correlates of positive emotions, and practical application of psychological resources such as optimism, resilience, and mindfulness.
Social-psychological analysis of organizations, emphasizing role-theory and systems theory.
Theory of test construction and psychological measurement. Statistical methods in measurement. Survey of existing tests.
Cross-listed: (See Ecology and Evolutionary Biology 450.)

Principles of communication in animals. Analyses of developmental, mechanistic, functional, and evolutionary influences on communicative signals. Information and coding, communication and social behavior, signal complexity and human language.
Cross-listed: (See Ecology and Evolutionary Biology 459.)
Nervous system and physiological mechanisms of behavior. Biological basis of emotion, learning, memory, and stress.
A review of the behavioral and neurobiological actions of all major psychoactive drugs, focusing on how drugs alter behavior by influencing brain mechanisms.
Major theories of human personality and their development.
Provides an overview of the psychological impact of traumatic events. Specific types of traumatic events will be discussed as well as treatment options for trauma-related disorders.

column2: PSYC 474 - Theories and Research in Child Development
column3: Survey of major theories and empirical research in the field of child development. Material will encompass areas such as motor, perceptual, cognitive, and emotional
Theoretical perspectives and empirical research findings pertinent to adolescent development.
Classical and current approaches to learning and cognition.
Intensive analysis of special topics, such as sustainability psychology or intersectionality.

Exploration of the biological, personal, and societal relevance of sleep. Topics spanning a cellular-level understanding of how sleep and dreams are generated by the brain to the effects of sleep disruption on both personal and public health and safety.
Intensive analysis of special topics, such as sustainability psychology or intersectionality.

column2: PSYC 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.

column2: PSYC 508 - Readings and Special Issues in Psychology

column3: Required of first-year graduate students in psychology.
Intensive examination of selected issues in psychology.
Normal processes of human socialization; physical, cognitive, and emotional development from conception through infancy, childhood, and adolescence.
Research and practical issues in experimental psychology.
History, theory, research and practice of counseling psychology.

column2: PSYC 519 - Advanced Theories and Interventions in Counseling Psychology
column3: Advanced training in application of counseling theories and interventions. Emphasis on developing theory driven case conceptualizations and treatment plans from a variety of theoretical perspectives.

column2: PSYC 521 - Analysis of Variance for Social Sciences
column3: Analysis of variance and statistical theory: application within social science framework. Contrasts among means, trend analysis, analysis of covariance, analysis of factorial designs, and multivariate approaches to analysis of within subject’s data.

column2: PSYC 522 - Multiple Regression for Social Sciences
column3: Complexities of regression analyses and theory: application within social science framework. Bivariate correlation and regression, multiple regression, analysis of variable sets, interactions among continuous predictors, reducing co-linearity between main effects and application of multiple regression to testing procedures of mediation and moderation.
Survey of experience-dependent changes in brain and behavior development.

Effects of psychoactive drugs on mood and behavior, emphasizing the mechanisms of drug action on neurotransmitter systems. Topics include the relationship between behavior and endogenous neurochemical activity, therapeutic agents used to treat mental disorders, and drugs of abuse.

column2: PSYC 526 - Research Methods in Behavioral Neuroscience

column3: Advanced analysis of the structure and function of the nervous system with an emphasis on neurobiological mechanisms controlling behavior.

column2: PSYC 528 - Seminar on College Teaching in Psychology
column3: Didactic seminar on essential pedagogical concepts for teaching at the college and/or university level.

column2: PSYC 529 - Practicum in College Teaching in Psychology
column3: Techniques, materials, and supervised preparation/practice in actual course instruction in psychology.
Survey of core topics on attitude formation, change, and measurement; roles of automatic and controlled processes, affect, cognition, and behavior in a variety of attitude domains.
Advanced analysis of the ecological and evolutionary bases of behavior.

column2: PSYC 547 - Conceptual Foundations of Evolution and Behavior
column3: Critical evaluation of seminal writings on theory and methods in comparative analysis of behavior.
Survey of theory and research concerning interpersonal interaction and individual behavior in social context.

Introduction to group theory, dynamics, and methods including: therapeutic factors in groups, group development, group climate and norms, leadership and co-leadership, multicultural considerations in group work, ethical issues in group work, group assessment/evaluation, group process and outcome research.

column2: PSYC 565 - History and Systems of Psychology
column3: History of philosophy concerning psychology. Major systems of psychology which emerged during 20th-century.
Supervised practice of individual counseling.
Didactic instruction in basic counseling techniques and interviewing skills.

column2: PSYC 570 - Cognitive and Affective Bases of Behavior
column3: Survey of current theoretical and empirical literature on the determinants of individual differences including cognitive (e.g., self-efficacy, schemas, attributions) and affective (e.g., information-processing, emotion regulation, inhibition of emotion) processes.

column2: PSYC 577 - Multicultural Psychology: Theory and Research
column3: Provides graduate students who are interested in mental health with a basic foundation of knowledge, awareness, and skills in multicultural issues. Covers theories, research, and counseling interventions for working effectively with clients from different socio-cultural groups.

column2: PSYC 579 - Practicum in Individual Assessment, Counseling
column3: Basic application of individually-administered, standardized assessment instruments: administration, scoring, and integrated interpretation. Supervision in adult evaluation, and referral/treatment planning. Instruments include WAIS; Stanford-Binet; MMPI, PAI, MCMI.
Developing questions, hypotheses, and research designs for empirical investigation in psychology.

column2: PSYC 593 - Independent, Off-campus, or Foreign Study

column3: Basic concepts and techniques of adult assessment: intelligence tests and personality tests.
Basic concepts and techniques of adult assessment, intelligence tests and personality tests.
Developmental aspects of behavior from a life course perspective and how normative development informs the development of psychopathology and vice versa.

column2: PSYC 598 - Ethical Issues in Professional Psychology
column3: Ethical, legal and professional issues in the conduct and process of science and practice in psychology.
Formal use of descriptive categories used in the diagnosis of abnormal behavior.

column2: PSYC 622 - Structural Equation Modeling for the Social Sciences
column3: Structural equation models, including confirmatory factor analysis, path analysis, hybrid models, and multiple group models approaches. Conceptualization and application of techniques.

column2: PSYC 645 - Seminar on Supervision, Professional Development, Internship, and Ethical Conduct
column3: Seminar course will include didactic training in supervision, information about preparation for internship, and exposure to and discussion about different career trajectories within Clinical Psychology.

column2: PSYC 660 - Responsible Conduct of Research in Behavioral Science
column3: Ethical issues in psychological research: advising and mentoring, authorship, conflicts of interest, data handling, human subjects, misconduct, non-human animal subjects.

Theory, research, and evaluation of neural bases of brain/behavior relationships, common syndromes and their behavioral and cognitive manifestations (e.g., neurodevelopmental syndromes, lifespan issues, etc.).
The purpose of this course is to assist the supervisor-in-training to develop knowledge and skills for the administration and supervision of the practice of counseling.

column2: PSYC 667 - Assessment in Counseling Psychology I
column3: Use and interpretation of measures commonly used in the practice of counseling psychology, including measures of cognitive ability, vocational, and personality assessment.

column2: PSYC 668 - Assessment in Counseling Psychology II
column3: Advanced use and interpretation of measures commonly used in the practice of counseling psychology, including measures of cognitive ability, psychopathology, and personality.
Introduction to psychotherapy: case conceptualization and treatment.
Advanced theories and techniques of psychotherapy.
Classification methods in psychopathology and use of the DSM for differential diagnosis and treatment options appropriate for counseling psychology and other mental health professionals.

column2: PSYC 674 - Advanced Practicum in Counseling Psychology
column3: Supervised advanced practice of individual and group counseling, also campus outreach interventions.

column2: PSYC 675 - Advanced Theory and Practice in Group Counseling
column3: Theories and supervised practice.

column2: PSYC 676 - Field Placement in Counseling Psychology
PSYC 678 - Theory and Practice of Counseling Supervision
column3: Theory and practice of supervision in counseling.

column2: PSYC 695 - Field Placement in Clinical Psychology
PSYC 698 - Seminar in Supervision and Consultation
column3: Basic and applied concepts and techniques of supervision and consultation.

column2: PSYC 699 - Pre-doctoral Internship in Clinical or Counseling Psychology
column3: Supervised employment in program approved psychology internship sites.
Discussion of the social, economic, political, environmental, and cultural determinants of health including measurements of health and burden of disease.

column2: PUBH 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.

column2: PUBH 509 - Graduate Seminar in Public Health
column3: In-depth discussion of timely topics reflecting scope of public health as  discipline and its interrelation with many other academic and professional  disciplines. Speakers both internal and external.
Study of the environmental factors (natural, anthropogenic or combination) on human health and the integrity of the ecosystem.

column2: PUBH 520 - Health Systems, Policy and Leadership
column3: Exploration of public health and healthcare systems, health policy formulation, and associated implications for management and leadership.

column2: PUBH 521 - Organizational Dynamics in Health Care
column3: The development of organizational theory and its effects on organizational dynamics in health care organizations in the private and public sectors. Case and problem-solving discussions, projects that demonstrate the needed skill sets.

column2: PUBH 525 - Financial Management of Health Programs
column3: Financial management concepts and practices applied to health services programs. Fundamentals of budgeting, costing, financing and reimbursement mechanisms for health and healthcare. Opportunities to apply techniques.

column2: PUBH 526 - Health Care and Public Health Systems
column3: An examination of the U.S. healthcare system – including public (Medicaid, Medicare) and private components of healthcare delivery – and public health systems in the United States, at the federal, tribal, state, territorial, and local levels; historical and legal foundations of public health; U.S. healthcare and public health within a global context.

column2: PUBH 527 - Healthcare Organizations: Behavior and Management
column3: Development of effective managers and leaders through understanding the interaction across individuals and groups within health and public health organizations. We will employ system-level thinking for problem-solving and strategic planning. Students will complete a service-learning component providing experience in a health-based organization and focused on planning or change management.
Application of descriptive and inferential statistical methods to analyze and interpret data for health-related problems and programs.

Research design, basic quantitative and qualitative research techniques and ethical considerations. Development of research skills, data collection instruments, and problem identification for research topic.

Introductory course on the different types of program evaluation, including formative research, process evaluation, monitoring of outcomes, impact assessment and cost analysis. Covers experimental, quasi-experimental and non-experimental study designs and the strengths and limitations of each.

The distribution and determinants of health-related outcomes in specified populations with application to control of health problems. Issues addressed include: historical origins of discipline, hypothesis formulation, research design, data and error sources, measures of frequency and association, etiologic reasoning, and disease screening.

column2: PUBH 541 - Student Outbreak Rapid Response Training
column3: Disease outbreak investigation, prevention, and control. Basic instruction on the steps involved in investigating a real disease outbreak, working in partnership with the Tennessee Department of Health, the Knox County Health Department, and the East Tennessee Regional Health Office. Following the initial session, students will be available throughout the semester to assist these public health offices in response to a call for expanded capacity to investigate and address a real disease outbreak. Requires at least four hours of community service learning.
Requires the application of behavioral sciences theory to the development and implementation of health promotion programs.
Applies an ecological framework to health assessment and program planning to address health disparities. Requires 25 or more hours of community service learning.

Provides students with an understanding of social and behavioral determinants that influence health status and care in America. The application of this knowledge to behavior in health-related organizations is emphasized. Topics include social and psychological aspects of disease, sociological aspects of health care delivery systems, the political economy of health and illness, impact of social movements on health, and social consequences of health legislation.

column2: PUBH 556 - Grant Proposal Writing for Health and Social Programs
column3: This project-based course covers the complete process of grant proposal development: identification and assessment of viable funding sources, funder relations, proposal writing, budget development, preparation of a full proposal for submission, and proposal submission. Students gain an understanding of the nonprofit philanthropic, state, and federal funding environments and how they differ.
Exploration of the organization, financing, reimbursement, and performance of the U.S. health care delivery from a systems perspective.
Internship in approved organization under supervision of designated preceptor. Students must complete a total of 6 credit hours.
Internship in either approved organization or research setting under supervision of designated preceptor.
Internship in either approved organization or research setting under supervision of designated preceptor.

Will further prepare the public health doctoral student for the dissertation process, including proper framing of a research question, conducting the literature review, and specification of methods. Students will lead discussions and presentations on methods being used in their dissertations and early results. Will also include an exploration of current health behavior and health education-related research being conducted across the University.

column2: PUBH 610 - Scientific Writing for the Health Sciences
column3: A one-hour graduate seminar focusing on the craft of writing for scientific publications. Students will gain experience in various writing styles, will learn techniques specific to scientific writing, will understand the importance of accurate referencing, and will gain experience in composing cover letters and how to respond to reviewers. Students will learn by writing and critiquing each other. A required course in the DrPH curriculum.

Leadership theory applied to public health practice, with a particular focus on the distinction – and overlap – between leadership and management. Identification of personal leadership skills and gaps in ability to apply leadership theory to practice through personal leadership assessments, mentoring from local leaders in practice, and skill-building exercises. Additional emphasis on leadership for planning process and organizational change. A required course in the DrPH curriculum.

column2: PUBH 612 - Health and Health Care Policy
column3: Cross-listed: (See Nursing 612.)

column2: PUBH 613 - Public Health Ethics and Law
column3: An introduction and overview of critical issues relating to law, ethics, and public health.  Examines the legal foundations of the American public health system and resulting ethical dilemmas that must be reconciled when the interests of the larger community are at odds with those of individuals.  Will explore ways in which government actions on behalf of the public’s health may conflict with the Constitutional rights of individuals and businesses.  Includes recognition of the scope and limitations of authority of health organizations, regulation of professions and tort litigation for the public’s health. A required course in the DrPH curriculum.

column2: PUBH 614 - Nursing Preceptorship in Health Policy
column3: Cross-listed: (See Nursing 614.)

Biostatistics is the application of statistics to biological problems. Offers advanced instruction in biostatistics, including the application of advanced inferential statistical methods to public health practice. Will cover a variety of multivariable modeling approaches, data management, and analysis planning and development.

column2: PUBH 634 - Physical Activity and Positive Health
column3: Cross-listed: (See Kinesiology 635.)

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are important components of the epidemiologist’s toolbox. They often provide the foundations for understanding the state of current research on a given exposure-outcome relationship, and may offer opportunities for future research topics.
Application of multivariate statistics to research questions in health behavior; analysis of public health data.

Integrating program planning and evaluation; working with community stakeholders; qualitative evaluation methods; study designs and data analysis strategies for experimental and quasi-experimental evaluations; preparing an evaluation proposal and budget.

column2: PUBH 640 - Advanced Epidemiology in Public Health
column3: Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related outcomes at the population level. Topics addressed include measures of disease, measures of effect, sources of error, advanced methodological issues unique to the observational and experimental study designs utilized in public health practice and research, causal inference, and screening and clinical epidemiology.
Design a system-level intervention, emphasizing best pedagogical practices in delivering an educational experience in a community setting.

column2: PUBH 656 - Comparative Theories in Health Behavior
column3: Theoretical models of health behavior; analysis, synthesis, and discussion of historical, contemporary and cross-cultural relevance of models; application of theory to research, prevention and intervention in public health; critical reading and evaluation of theory-based research on health behavior.
Internship in a public health practice setting, approved by the academic advisor and DrPH Program Director. See DrPH Graduate Handbook for further information and documentation.
Individual study of selected issues.

Research, planning and communication, and evaluation of major public relations campaigns. Oral and written presentation of a public relations project from inception to completion. Requires extensive out-of-class work.
Topics vary.

column2: PBRL 502 - Registration for Use of Facilities
column3: Required for the student not otherwise registered during any semester when the student uses university facilities and/or faculty time before degree is completed.

column2: PBRL 516 - Seminar in Public Relations Issues
column3: Topics vary.
Cross-listed: (See Journalism and Electronic Media 525.)
Emphasis on theoretical and practical applications to preparing for and engaging in crisis communication and management, including risk communication and issues management.

Theories of leadership and management and organizational structure and functions of public relations agencies and departments in public, private, and non-profit sectors. Analysis and management of problems in communication between organizations and their publics with emphasis on ethics and standards of the profession.

Strategic communication planning to achieve overall goals of organizations. Emphasis on decision making, the budgeting process, including cost-benefit analysis of tactics, and managerial execution of public relations plans. Measurement and evaluation of effectiveness of communication programs.

column2: PBRL 561 - Social Media in Advertising and Public Relations
column3: Cross-listed: (See Advertising 561.)
Capstone project under guidance of faculty. Application of principles from previous course work.
Cross-listed: (See Journalism and Electronic Media 680.)

column2: REED 461 - Developing Reading Skills in Content Fields
column3: Teaching reading and study skills in content areas of school program. Extensive assessment of textbooks. Emphasis on middle school and high school.
Strategies for integration of language, writing, content, literature, and higher level thinking skills (K-12).
Theory and practice in emergent literacy. Focus on the development of early reading and writing from preschool through first grade.
